item.title: Rally Gives Way to Skepticism on Dollar, Stocks
item.description: Dollar is weakening again after its biggest rally since election
item.dc:creator: Vassilis Karamanis, Phil Serafino

item.title: Bearish Stock Investors Left to Chase Rally, BofA Poll Shows
item.description: Investors are likely to be forced to chase the stock rally sparked by the US-China trade truce after mostly missing out on last month’s rebound, Bank of America Corp. strategists said.
item.dc:creator: Sagarika Jaisinghani

item.title: Tariffs Impact on Credit Markets
item.description: A growing number of companies financed by private lenders are showing signs of stress. That's according to first quarter results from business development companies, which lend to SMEs. Meanwhile, market watchers say that trend is likely to be exacerbated by the global trade war. Robert Dafforn, Chief Investment Officer of Opportunistic Credit at Polus Capital Management speaks to Bloomberg's Francine Lacqua on what this means for the industry. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Marubeni CEO Aligned With Buffett on Long-Term Partnership
item.description: The top executive at Marubeni Corp. affirmed the Japanese trading house’s commitment to a long-term partnership with Berkshire Hathaway Inc., echoing sentiments recently expressed by the US investment firm.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Stapczynski

item.title: Earnings Momentum Turns Positive for US Stocks as Tariffs Ease
item.description: The negative earnings-growth momentum that has plagued US equities for months is finally taking a turn for the better.
item.dc:creator: Michael Msika

media:content.media:description: A trader on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange.

item.title: Dollar’s Big Bounce Meets a Wall of Doubt in Options Market
item.description: The dollar pared Monday’s gains, with traders unconvinced that its recent surge on the back of easing US-China trade tensions will last long.
item.dc:creator: Vassilis Karamanis

item.title: Ghana’s Mahama Fine Tuning Regime to Accelerate Crude Extraction
item.description: Ghana is encouraging investors to get the country’s crude out of the ground to avoid the assets from getting stranded amid a global decarbonization push.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Zabasajja, Kamailoudini Tagba, Ekow Dontoh

item.title: SBB Surges on Aker Deal as CEO Flags Benefits to Creditors
item.description: Shares and bonds in Sweden’s SBB rallied on Tuesday after Norwegian industrial investment group Aker ASA became the commercial landlord’s new main shareholder.
item.dc:creator: Charles Daly

media:content.media:description: A Samhallsbyggnadsbolaget i Norden AB sign on a property managed by the company in Stockholm.

item.title: Porsche Braces for Sales Dip Over Trump’s Tariff Chaos
item.description: Porsche AG is expecting a dip in sales after consumers pulled forward purchases earlier this year to beat US President Donald Trump’s auto tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Monica Raymunt

item.title: Trump Faces $2 Trillion Hurdle to Win Money From Saudi Prince
item.description: US President Donald Trump’s hopes of securing as much as $1 trillion in investment commitments from Saudi Arabia might clash with another costly ambition - transforming the kingdom’s own economy.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Martin, Zainab Fattah

media:content.media:description: An illustration of Neom's planned Line Development, provided in March 2024.

item.title: India Proposes First Counter Move Against Trump’s Tariff Regime
item.description: India has proposed levies on some US goods in response to Washington’s duties on steel and aluminum, marking its first retaliation against President Donald Trump’s tariff regime, even as the two countries move closer to finalizing a trade deal.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Srivastava

media:content.media:description: A crane is used to load stainless steel coils onto a train container at Jindal Stainless Ltd. plant in Jajpur, Odisha, India, on Thursday, April 24, 2025. India is scheduled to release industrial production figures on April 28. Photographer: Anindito Mukherjee/Bloomberg

item.title: US Stock Futures Drop Before Key Inflation Data: Markets Wrap
item.description: The Wall Street stocks rally was set to pause as optimism around tariff cuts between the US and China gave way to lingering concern about inflation and economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Margaryta Kirakosian

item.title: Copper Steadies as Traders Weigh US-China Deal and Inflation
item.description: Industrial metals including copper were broadly steady, as traders weighed the impact of the US-China trade truce against ongoing concerns about inflation and economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ryan

media:content.media:description: A crane unloads iron ore from a barge at the Thyssenkrupp Steel Europe AG steel plant in Duisburg, Germany. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

item.title: The Problem With the Fed Isn’t Independence, It’s Accountability
item.description: Monetary policy is too technical to be left to the politicians and too political to be left to the technocrats.
item.dc:creator: Tom Orlik

media:content.media:description: Photographer: Scott Semler for Bloomberg Businessweek. Prop Stylist: Andrea Bonin

item.title: Vietnam Tycoon Seeks to Manage Her Assets From Prison, Media Reports
item.description: Vietnamese property tycoon Truong My Lan sent a letter from her prison cell asking authorities to reevaluate the wealth of her assets, as she seeks to pay back some of the billions embezzled and avoid the death penalty.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Stevens

media:content.media:description: Vietnamese property tycoon Truong My Lan (C) looks on at a court in Ho Chi Minh City on November 4, 2024. The appeal of a Vietnamese property tycoon given the death penalty for fraud totalling $27 billion will begin on November 4, after she pleaded for a more "lenient and humane" sentence. (Photo by STRINGER / AFP) (Photo by STRINGER/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Goldman Lifts S&P 500 Targets With Caution on Market Optimism
item.description: The outlook for US equities is improving as trade tensions with China ease, though pricing is already looking optimistic given lingering uncertainties, according to Goldman Sachs Group Inc. strategists.
item.dc:creator: John Cheng

media:content.media:description: Goldman Sachs Group Inc. signage on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Tuesday, April 8, 2025. Stocks surged at the fastest pace since 2022 and bonds fell after Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent fueled hopes of trade deals, marking a dramatic shift in Wall Street sentiment following a selloff that chopped trillions of dollars off global markets. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: What to Expect From the April CPI Report
item.description: US inflation likely accelerated in April with higher tariffs on Chinese goods in particular starting to impact prices. The consumer price index is seen rising 0.3% from March after declining in the prior month. Michael McKee has a preview on Bloomberg Television.

item.title: KNDS Sues Triton Over Refusal to Deliver 18% Renk Stake
item.description: KNDS NV has sued Triton Partners for refusing to transfer a stake in key tank supplier Renk Group AG, escalating a legal battle between the Franco-German defense company and buyout firm.
item.dc:creator: Eyk Henning

media:content.media:description: An employee checks a Marder tank gear transmission at the Renk plant in Augsburg, Germany.

item.title: Sinopec Seeks $994 Million Via Bonds Exchangeable Into Stock
item.description: Sinopec, China’s biggest crude oil processor, is seeking to raise HK$7.75 billion ($994 million) from the sale of exchangeable bonds to refinance existing offshore debt.
item.dc:creator: Julia Fioretti

media:content.media:description: A Sinopec gas station in Shanghai. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: Pension Funds Agree to Invest 5% Into UK Private Assets
item.description: As UK pension fund managers agree to invest at least 5% of their assets into UK private markets, Chancellor Rachel Reeves says she hopes the deal will unlock billions of pounds for infrastructure projects and local startups, but she won't rule out mandating funds to invest. Alastair King, Lord Mayor of the City of London, and Andy Briggs, Chief Executive of Phoenix Group both join Bloomberg's Francine Lacqua to discuss how this could impact the UK economy. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Traders Model Bullish Moves for S&P 500 With Tariff Tensions Easing
item.description: The reprieve in US-China trade tensions that sent stocks soaring on Monday has chart watchers anticipating fresh all-time highs for the S&P 500 Index.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Kniazhevich

item.title: Larry Fink Sees Volatility Lingering Even as Trade Tensions Ease
item.description: Some of the world’s top financial leaders are preparing for continued market volatility despite the US-China trade truce — but say the uncertainty is also creating new openings for investment.
item.dc:creator: Nandu Nair

media:content.media:description: Larry Fink and Jane Fraser on May 13. Source: Saudi-US Investment Forum

item.title: German Investor Confidence Jumps on Progress Over Tariffs
item.description: Investor confidence in Germany’s economy improved as the initial shock from US tariffs fades and a new government prepares to boost public spending.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber

item.title: Oil Holds Relief Gain as Focus Turns to Trump in Middle East
item.description: Oil held on to its recent recovery as attention moved away from the deescalation of the US-China trade war towards the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Alex Longley, Sarah Chen

item.title: US Treasuries Gain as Traders Eye Inflation for Clues on Fed
item.description: Treasuries gained ahead of the release of US inflation data, paring sharp losses sparked by the temporary US-China trade truce that’s dimmed the odds of a global recession.
item.dc:creator: Liz Capo McCormick

item.title: Nissan Shuts Plants, Slashes Jobs After Worst Loss in 25 Years
item.description: Nissan Motor Co. vowed to close seven factories and cut 20,000 jobs after posting its biggest annual loss since French carmaker Renault SA rescued the company from near bankruptcy a quarter century ago.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Takahashi

media:content.media:description: Ivan Espinosa in Yokohama on May 13.

item.title: Griffin Says Cash May Have Been Best in Tariff Turmoil
item.description: As markets soared on a truce in the trade war between the US and China, Citadel founder Ken Griffin reflected on the past month, suggesting it would have been better to sit on the sidelines in cash. Griffin spoke with Bloomberg News' Sonali Basak during a taping of an episode of the upcoming series Bullish for Bloomberg Originals at the Four Seasons in Miami. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Citadel’s Griffin Says Going to Cash May Have Been Best in Tariff Turmoil
item.description: As markets soared on a truce in the trade war between the US and China, Citadel founder Ken Griffin reflected on the past month, suggesting it would have been better to sit on the sidelines in cash.
item.dc:creator: Sonali Basak, Dasha Afanasieva

item.title: Gold Recovers With Inflation in Focus After Haven Asset Selloff
item.description: Gold rebounded as investors focused on a key US inflation report, after the precious metal slumped with other haven assets on Monday following a trade truce between Washington and Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Sybilla Gross, Jack Ryan

media:content.media:description: Gold bars, part of the Czech National Bank's reserves arranged in Prague, Czech Republic, on Tuesday, Feb. 25, 2025. Gold’s recent record-breaking run has been broadly supported by haven demand, amid concern and increasing confusion over US President Donald Trump’s plan to enact sweeping tariffs. Photographer: Milan Jaros/Bloomberg

item.title: Bayer Surges After Earnings Beat Estimates on New Drug Sales
item.description: Bayer AG’s shares surged after its earnings beat expectations, with robust demand for its new cancer and kidney medicines helping offset a decline in agricultural sales.
item.dc:creator: Tim Loh

media:content.media:description: The logo of Bayer AG at the company's pharmaceutical campus in Berlin, Germany, on Monday, Feb. 27, 2023. Bayer AG sees lower profit this year as it contends with falling prices for agriculture products in its crop science division, although the pharma division will probably see another year of about 1% sales growth and the consumer health unit could see sales rise by about 5%, it said. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg
